en.purpose: To assess Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Functional Assessment.
en.use: Used for children aged 4 years and older, as well as adolescents. Minimum 2 of the criteria must be fulfilled to get positive diagnostic result.
en.misuse:
Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional constipation may be present:
- constipation onset extremely early in life (<1 month old)
- passage of meconium >48 hours after delivery
- family history of Hirschsprung disease
- ribbon stools
- blood in the stools in the absence of anal fissures
- failure to thrive or unintentional weight loss
- fever
- bilious vomiting
- severe abdominal distension
- fecal incontinence in the absence of rectal impaction
- abnormal physical exam findings
- simultaneous urinary retention or incontinence

gt0001.text: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Child Functional Constipation Assessment
gt0001.description:
The Rome IV criteria provide symptom-based guidelines for diagnosing disorders of gut-brain interaction (DGBI) in children and adolescents, including functional constipation. Earlier versions of the Rome criteria relied primarily on expert consensus, as research on pediatric and adolescent DGBI was still limited.

Functional constipation should be diagnosed based on clinical history, physical examination, and minimal laboratory testing when necessary. These criteria apply to children over 4 years old and adolescents who have experienced symptoms suggestive of constipation for at least one month. Such symptoms may include passing hard, painful stools, fecal incontinence, or withholding behaviors.

gt0020.text: ≤2 defecations in the toilet per week

gt0021.text: ≥1 episode of fecal incontinence per week

gt0022.text: History of retentive posturing or excessive volitional stool retention

gt0023.text: History of painful or hard bowel movements

gt0024.text: Presence of a large fecal mass in the rectum

gt0025.text: History of large diameter stools which can obstruct the toilet

gt0026.text: After appropriate evaluation, the symptoms cannot be fully explained by another medical condition

gt0027.text: Occurring ≥1 time per week for a minimum of 1 month

gt0028.text: Insufficient criteria for a diagnosis of IBS
